author: pietjepuk
content: No, you set a maxFeePerGas and a maxPriorityFeePerGas. The former is the max on the sum of the base fee and the priority fee. And that one in turn cannot be higher than maxPriorityFeePerGas.

author: pietjepuk
content:
Say you set a fee cap of 200 Gwei, and a priority fee cap of 100 Gwei.

If the base fee for a certain block is 150 Gwei, then you end up paying 200 Gwei (your cap). You pay (=burned) 150 Gwei for the base fee, and 50 Gwei goes to the miner.

author: pietjepuk
content: If you want "traditional style" transactions, you set the fee cap equal to the priority fee cap (or you can even set the latter higher if you want). Then you _always_ end up paying the fee cap, just like you would now always pay the entire gas fee if your tx goes through.

author: pietjepuk
content: For many users that only care about inclusion (and not position), the maxPriorityFeePerGas will be set to 1 Gwei by the wallet (and hidden from the user). The wallet will also set the fee cap to something like 2 x the current base fee (and also hide this from the user by default)

author: pietjepuk
content: So if the base fee is 150 Gwei (like before), a typical tx could have a fee cap of 300 Gwei and a priority fee cap of 1 Gwei. If the base fee stays the same, you end up paying 151 Gwei (150 of which is burned, 1 goes to miner) per unit of gas.
